question_text: In philosophy, physicalism is the thesis that everything that exists is what?
correct_answer: Physical, or entirely dependent on and determined by physical entities and properties
distractors: Mental, originating from consciousness and irreducible to any material substrate whatsoever
Logical, consisting of abstract formal relations that ground all observable natural phenomena
Linguistic, constituted by the symbolic structures of language that shape perceived reality

question_text: What distinguishes abstract objects from concrete objects in metaphysics?
correct_answer: Abstract objects lack spatiotemporal location and causal powers, unlike concrete objects
distractors: Abstract objects are perceptible through the senses while concrete objects require inference
Abstract objects exist only in the future whereas concrete objects exist in the present
Abstract objects are created by physical processes while concrete objects arise from thought

question_text: In Aristotelian metaphysics, what does the essence of a thing refer to?
correct_answer: The set of necessary properties that make a thing what it fundamentally is
distractors: The accidental qualities a thing acquires through interaction with its environment
The material substrate from which a thing is physically composed at any moment
The sensory impressions a thing produces in the minds of its various observers

question_text: In modal logic, what makes a proposition contingent rather than necessary?
correct_answer: It is true in some possible worlds but false in others, depending on how things happen to be
distractors: It is true in every possible world and could not have been false under any circumstances
It is false in every possible world and its negation holds as a matter of logical law
It is neither true nor false in any possible world because it lacks determinate meaning

question_text: What does supervenience mean in philosophy of mind?
correct_answer: Mental properties cannot differ without a corresponding difference in underlying physical properties
distractors: Physical properties are entirely caused by and reducible to prior mental states and intentions
Mental and physical properties vary completely independently with no systematic correlation at all
Higher-level mental properties replace and eliminate the lower-level physical properties they describe

question_text: What is the core claim of nominalism in metaphysics?
correct_answer: Only particular concrete things exist; universals and abstract objects are merely names or labels
distractors: Universal forms exist independently of particular things in a separate realm of abstract being
Both universals and particulars exist equally as fundamental constituents of mind-independent reality
Abstract mathematical objects are the only true existents and physical particulars are derivative

question_text: The problem of universals asks whether properties shared by multiple objects, such as redness, exist independently of those objects. What are the two main realist answers?
correct_answer: Platonic realism, where universals exist independently of particulars, and Aristotelian realism, where universals exist only within particulars
distractors: Cartesian realism, where universals exist in the mind, and Kantian realism, where universals structure possible experience
Empirical realism, where universals are discovered by observation, and rational realism, where universals are deduced a priori
Constructive realism, where universals are social agreements, and eliminative realism, where universals are reducible to physics

question_text: According to the psychological continuity theory of personal identity, what makes a person at one time the same person at a later time?
correct_answer: Overlapping chains of psychological connections such as memories, beliefs, and personality traits
distractors: Continuous possession of an immaterial soul that remains numerically identical through all bodily changes
Unbroken physical continuity of the same biological organism from birth through natural death
Ongoing social recognition by others who consistently identify and treat the individual as the same person

question_text: Compatibilism holds that free will and determinism are mutually compatible. How do compatibilists typically define a free action?
correct_answer: An action performed according to the agent's own desires and motivations without external coercion or constraint
distractors: An action that is completely uncaused, arising from a spontaneous quantum event in the agent's neural processes
An action chosen from among genuinely open alternative possibilities that are not fixed by prior causal history
An action whose outcome the agent could not have predicted because of inherent randomness in the causal chain

question_text: What is mereology the formal study of in philosophy?
correct_answer: Part-whole relations and how parts compose or constitute larger wholes
distractors: Cause-effect relations and how prior events necessitate subsequent outcomes
Set-membership relations and how individual elements belong to abstract classes
Mind-body relations and how mental states interact with physical processes
